evidence.evidence_text: 773 mounds from TRAP 2009-2011 pedestrian survey, Kazanlak Valley, 85 sq km
evidence.verbatim_quote: In this study we used a dataset of 773 mounds, collected by TRAP during 2009–2011 field survey in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria... This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey
the model reported good learning and model fit (F1 5 0.87)

evidence.evidence_text: First model field validation: 19/148 tiles (12.8%) true positive, 129/148 (87.1%) false positive
evidence.verbatim_quote: only 19 out of 148 tiles (12.8%) tagged by the model with at least a 60% chance of having a mound actually contained one... Some 129 of the tagged tiles (87.1%) were false positives

evidence.evidence_text: First model: 38/773 mounds detected (4.9%), 95.3% false negative rate
evidence.verbatim_quote: The 19 true-positive tiles contained 38 mounds (1–9 mounds per tile), out of 773 in the study area (4.9%)... a false negative rate of 95.3%
The second model's performance declined to an F1 score of 0.62

evidence.evidence_text: Second model: 21/773 mounds detected (2.7%), 273/288 tiles (94.8%) false positive
evidence.verbatim_quote: only 21 of 773 mounds (2.7%) were detected... The remaining 273 of 288 tiles were false positives (94.8%)
Developing our CNN model required approximately 135 person-hours from conceptualisation and experiments to validation and documentation

evidence.evidence_text: Model: ResNet-50 pre-trained CNN, TensorFlow 2, Python
evidence.verbatim_quote: we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data... The model was deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python
In the 2021 run of the model, we used all 773 cutouts... In the 2022 run, we selected 249 cutouts where a mound was discernible with the naked eye

evidence.evidence_text: Literature review: 44/70 papers (63%) fail to mention negative aspects of AI/ML
evidence.verbatim_quote: 44 abstracts (63%) fail to mention any negative aspects of AI/ML approaches at all

evidence.evidence_text: Three GitHub repositories with complete analysis code
evidence.verbatim_quote: scripts are available in public repositories: (1) https://github.com/adivea/cnn-testing (2) https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/burial-mounds (3) https://github.com/centre-for-humanities-computing/MoundDetection

evidence.evidence_text: IKONOS imagery: 600 sq km, 1m panchromatic, 4m multispectral
evidence.verbatim_quote: two IKONOS scenes covering 600 sq km... panchromatic band at 1 m resolution and a multispectral image (RGBNIR) at 4 m resolution

evidence.evidence_text: ML publications: 21 papers (17% of 125) in archaeological remote sensing 2023
evidence.verbatim_quote: These 21 publications represent about 17% of the 2023 total (n=125) for archaeological remote sensing
The ratio of positive to negative training data was approximately 1:2 (32%–68%)

evidence.evidence_text: Only 4/70 papers (6%) discuss partial or complete failures
evidence.verbatim_quote: four (6%) discuss attempts to deploy ML that ended in partial or complete failures

claims.claim_text: Study tests CNN transfer learning for burial mound detection against 773 field-verified mounds in Kazanlak Valley
claims.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery

claims.claim_text: External validation against field data is essential for CNN archaeological prospection workflows
claims.verbatim_quote: The model has detected incidental features rather than the mounds themselves, making external validation with field data an essential part of CNN workflows

claims.claim_text: First model failed: reported F1=0.87 but only 4.9% actual detection rate
claims.verbatim_quote: Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features with other phenomena

claims.claim_text: Self-reported ML metrics are misleadingly high compared to actual archaeological feature detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high, and that the model was misidentifying most features

claims.claim_text: Second model (curated training data) performed worse than first model: F1=0.62, 2.7% detection
claims.verbatim_quote: Counterintuitively, the model provided with training data selected for highly visible mounds (rather than all mounds) performed worse

claims.claim_text: Additional training data curation worsened rather than improved model performance
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, despite additional curation of the training data, the second run was even less successful than the first

claims.claim_text: Manual approaches (expert inspection, crowdsourcing) would likely be more efficient given 135h investment and poor results
claims.verbatim_quote: In our case, given the size of our study area and the number of features it likely contains, manual approaches like visual inspection by experts or crowdsourcing to volunteers would probably be more efficient

claims.claim_text: ML-for-archaeology literature exhibits publication bias with overwhelmingly positive reporting
claims.verbatim_quote: The literature itself, however, is overwhelmingly positive, reflecting some combination of publication bias and a rhetoric of unconditional success

claims.claim_text: Complete code transparency achieved via three public GitHub repositories
claims.verbatim_quote: Data processing and analysis was performed using R and Python and the scripts are available in public repositories

claims.claim_text: AI/ML approaches are nearing mainstream adoption (17% of publications) in archaeological remote sensing
claims.verbatim_quote: If publication counts are used a proxy for research, this 17% figure indicates that AI/ML is on the cusp of 'crossing the chasm'

claims.claim_text: CNN detected background features (forest edges, roads, shorelines) rather than target mounds
claims.verbatim_quote: Overall, the model seemed to select bright lines and edges (forest, roads), rather than round shapes more likely to represent mounds

claims.claim_text: This paper provides cautionary counterbalance for potential ML adopters in archaeology
claims.verbatim_quote: This paper presents the failure of a good-faith attempt to utilise these approaches as a counterbalance and cautionary tale to potential adopters of the technology

claims.claim_text: Pre-trained CNNs with low-touch training fail for varied features in heterogeneous landscapes
claims.verbatim_quote: Our attempt to deploy a pre-trained CNN demonstrates the limitations of this approach when it is used to detect varied features of different sizes within a heterogeneous landscape that contains confounding natural and modern features

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Field validation provides more reliable performance assessment than self-reported ML metrics
trigger_text: Validation of results against field data showed that self-reported success rates were misleadingly high
Although the first model reported a good fit (F1 = 0.87), validation with field data showed the model was confusing our target features
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Dramatic gap between F1 scores (0.87, 0.62) and actual detection rates (4.9%, 2.7%) demonstrates that field validation reveals failures hidden by standard metrics.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Transfer learning assumptions may not hold for archaeological applications with heterogeneous targets
trigger_text: Transfer learning assumes that large, complex models can be pre-trained using data from one domain, then fine-tuned for a specific task in another domain

Our outcomes indicate that even an advanced pre-trained model... is likely to fail when asked to detect somewhat variable features against very heterogeneous backgrounds with only a low-touch approach to training
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: The paper tests transfer learning assumptions and finds they fail for archaeological detection in complex landscapes, challenging applicability to HASS domains.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Publication bias creates unrealistic expectations for ML practitioners
trigger_text: The overwhelmingly positive tone of these papers likely indicates a certain degree of 'publication bias'
Early-majority adopters may find ML difficult to implement effectively in real-life scenarios
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Connection between publication bias and adoption difficulties implies biased literature creates expectations gap for new practitioners.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Resource reporting enables informed cost-benefit decisions
trigger_text: We also present time, expertise and resourcing requirements, a rarity in ML-for-archaeology publications
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Emphasis on rare resource reporting implies this information necessary for informed decision-making about ML adoption.

implicit_arguments.argument_text: Negative results have scientific value for advancing methodological understanding
trigger_text: it is important to document unsuccessful attempts to apply ML techniques to archaeological remote sensing
This paper offers a cautionary tale about the challenges, limitations, and demands of ML
implicit_arguments.inference_reasoning: Framing failure as valuable contribution implies negative results advance knowledge by helping others avoid similar pitfalls.

research_designs.design_text: Hypothesis-testing design for CNN transfer learning evaluation
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We set out to detect burial mounds in the Kazanlak Valley, Bulgaria, using IKONOS high-resolution satellite imagery. We developed a pre-trained CNN that was further trained

research_designs.design_text: Comparative experimental design testing two training strategies
research_designs.verbatim_quote: We first used an indiscriminate collection of burial mounds, regardless of their visibility in the satellite imagery. We next used only those mounds that we deemed easily discernible in the satellite imagery

research_designs.design_text: External validation design using independent field ground truth
research_designs.verbatim_quote: After this training, we applied the models to our imagery and validated results using our field data

methods.method_text: Transfer learning with pre-trained ResNet-50 CNN
methods.verbatim_quote: Rather than training our own model from scratch, we used a pre-trained CNN, a technique known as transfer learning... we concluded that ResNet-50 seemed to perform best for our data

methods.method_text: Pedestrian survey for ground truth collection
methods.verbatim_quote: This fieldwork covered some 85 sq km, inspected directly via pedestrian survey
After the initial performance evaluation, we manually validated model performance. To do so, we verified mound predictions using points marking ground-truthed mounds

methods.method_text: Systematic literature review via Web of Science
methods.verbatim_quote: Figure 2 displays the annual publication count in each of the past 10 years (n=70) in Web of Science

protocols.protocol_text: Training data preparation: 150x150m square cutouts from GPS centroids, MOUND/NOT MOUND classification, augmentation, 70:20:10 train/validation/test split
protocols.verbatim_quote: Mound points taken during fieldwork were used as centroids for the generation of 150 x 150 m square polygons... cutouts were divided into training, validation, and test sets following a 70:20:10 ratio

protocols.protocol_text: TensorFlow 2 deployment with data augmentation to counter overfitting
protocols.verbatim_quote: The model was deployed using TensorFlow 2 in Python... we used proven data augmentation techniques to constrain model performance

protocols.protocol_text: Field recording: GPS, height, diameter, land use, preservation status
protocols.verbatim_quote: Each mound was recorded with a GPS point, height, diameter, and surface and surrounding land use, as well as preservation status using Likert scale

protocols.protocol_text: Validation: filter >0.599 probability, generate 150m polygons, intersect with ground truth, classify TP/FP/FN
protocols.verbatim_quote: We selected prediction records whose mound-probability exceeded 0.599 and used the coordinates to generate square polygons of 150 m side. We intersected these polygons with the points marking ground-truthed mounds

protocols.protocol_text: Web of Science literature search with manual relevance review
protocols.verbatim_quote: in Web of Science for 'topic' including 'archaeology', and 'remote sensing or satellite image', and 'machine learning or artificial intelligence'... manually reviewed to eliminate any publications that did not in fact discuss archaeology or ML/AI

repositories.name: cnn-testing
repositories.description: Training data preparation and CNN prediction validation

repositories.name: burial-mounds
repositories.description: 2021 CNN classifier training and mound prediction

repositories.name: MoundDetection
repositories.description: 2022 CNN classifier training and mound prediction

machine_actionability.rationale: Complete code in public repositories but no formal environment specification

data_availability.description: Commercial IKONOS imagery cannot be redistributed; field data available through TRAP published reports

machine_actionability.rationale: Commercial satellite imagery restrictions prevent data sharing

author_contributions.details: Team: two digital archaeologists, ML specialist with heritage experience, junior developer
